summary: This is a memorandum from the Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General (OIG) to the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) providing a status update on the BOP's response to recommendations from the OIG's June 2023 final report on the custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. It details the BOP's progress on eight policy and procedural recommendations aimed at preventing future inmate suicides and improving security.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased inmate whose suicide while in BOP custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center prompted the OIG investigation and the subsequent recommendations this memorandum addresses.

events.title: OIG Final Report Release
events.description: The Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General issued its final report on the investigation and review of the BOP's custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: BOP Status Update Submission
events.description: The Federal Bureau of Prisons submitted a status update to the OIG in response to the recommendations from the June 2023 report.

events.title: BOP Incentives Reduction
events.description: The BOP reported that due to budgetary constraints, it is reducing or eliminating the use of recruitment and retention incentives for staff.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York, New York
keyFacts: The OIG's investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death resulted in eight recommendations to the BOP; one is closed and the other seven are 'Resolved' but not yet fully implemented as of this 2025 update.

The BOP is in the process of revising multiple Program Statements (e.g., on suicide prevention, unit management, correctional services) to address the recommendations, but these revisions are subject to union negotiation and policy development processes.

The BOP reported improvements in staff retention rates (overall and for Correctional Officers and Nurse Practitioners) due to incentives, but stated it is reducing or eliminating those incentives effective March 23, 2025, due to budget constraints.

Key unresolved issues include finalizing policy revisions on cellmate assignment after suicide watch, procedures for high-risk inmates, visit approvals, inmate wellbeing checks, lieutenant rounds, staffing shortages, and security camera system protocols.
